title: The Master and Margarita
author: Mikhail Bulgakov
plot: Set in Soviet Moscow, the devil appears disguised as a mysterious man named Woland, throwing the city’s literary elite into chaos. Meanwhile, a retelling of the trial of Jesus unfolds, revealing a poignant love story between the Master, a tormented writer, and Margarita, his devoted lover. As the two narratives intertwine, the consequences of greed, power, and faith come crashing down, leading to existential reflections and absurd happenings that force the characters—and readers—to question reality and morality.
buzz: This novel is often dubbed a cult classic, celebrated for its surreal blend of satire, fantasy, and romance. Readers either get swept up in its chaos and rich themes or find themselves overwhelmed by its complexities. It’s a love-it-or-hate-it kind of read, with a dedicated fanbase admiring its depth and humor.
matters: Reading *The Master and Margarita* today feels fresh as it grapples with themes of power struggles and the search for love amidst turmoil. The absurdity and satire resonate in our current world, reminding us of personal freedoms and the absurdity of societal norms.
taste: Bulgakov's sharp wit and lyrical prose shine through when Woland quips, ‘Manuscripts don’t burn,’ highlighting the enduring power of art in a world where everything else can turn chaotic.
